title: Praktikum 2
text: In this session, we will cover the first steps in SPSS, including the descriptive analysis of a single variable and the (apparent) relationship between two variables. The following methods will be applied today:

title: Praktikum 2
text:
Task 1


Timer

                    
                    
                

What is the level of measurement (scale type) for Gender/sex, Body Mass Index (BMI), and BMI categories?
First, answer this question based on your knowledge from the lecture, and then check whether the variables are correctly coded in SPSS.
To do this, switch from the Data View to the Variable View.‚öôÔ∏è



Show Results










Variable
(SPSS) Scale type
General type
Values




Gender
Nominal
unordered categorical
Male, Female


BMI
Scale
Continous



BMI categories
Nominal (?)
ordered categorical
< 18.5, 18.5-25, 25-30 - \(\geq\) 30









Tip




unordered vs ordered categorical?
scale if you can, for example, meaningfully add, subtract, or average




How does the level of measurement (scale level) of the variable number of teeth differ from that of body height or BMI index?


Show Results










Variable
Nature
SPSS Measure
Comment




BMI
Continuous numeric
Scale
Can take decimal values


Number of teeth
Discrete numeric
Scale
Only integer values, but still numeric

Tip



Which variable you assign to the rows or columns is up to you. However, it may be helpful to think of a consistent system ‚Äî for example, ‚ÄúOutcome on top,‚Äù meaning the outcome variable is placed in the columns.

title: Praktikum 2
text:
Task 4


Timer

                    
                    
                

Calculate the risk difference, relative risk, and odds ratio for the association between diabetes and periodontitis.
üí° In SPSS: ANALYSIEREN ‚Üí DESKRIPTIVE STATISTIKEN ‚Üí KREUZTABELLEN
Then in the Crosstabs dialog, click [Cells‚Ä¶] and under Percentages, select Row, then click Continue.
Next, click [Statistics‚Ä¶], check Risk, and click Continue.
Calculate manually:

Risk difference (RD):
Subtract the percentage values \[
RD = p_{\text{diabetic with periodontitis}} - p_{\text{non-diabetic with periodontitis}}
\]
Relative risk (RR):
Divide the percentage values instead of subtracting them.
\[
RR = \frac{p_{\text{diabetic with periodontitis}}}{p_{\text{non-diabetic with periodontitis}}}
\]
Odds ratio (OR):
Verify the value shown under ‚ÄúOdds ratio for ‚Ä¶‚Äù by calculating:

The odds of periodontitis for diabetics:
\[
\text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}} =
\frac{\text{number of diabetics with periodontitis}}
     {\text{number of diabetics without periodontitis}}
\]
Divided by the odds of periodontitis for non-diabetics:
\[
\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}} =
\frac{\text{number of non-diabetics with periodontitis}}
     {\text{number of non-diabetics without periodontitis}}
\]
Hence:
\[
OR = \frac{\text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}}}{\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}}}
= \frac{a/b}{c/d} = \frac{a \times d}{b \times c}
\]


where:
- ( a ): diabetics with periodontitis
- ( b ): diabetics without periodontitis
- ( c ): non-diabetics with periodontitis
- ( d ): non-diabetics without periodontitis

Let the 2√ó2 table be:




Periodontitis (+)
Periodontitis (‚àí)




Diabetic
( a )
( b )


Non-diabetic
( c )
( d )






Show Results

diab √ó perio2 Crosstabulation










diab

perio2 = periodontitis
perio2 = no
Total




diabetes
Count
199
578
777



% within diab
25.6%
74.4%
100.0%


no
Count
988
6,290
7,278



% within diab
13.6%
86.4%
100.0%


Total
Count
1,187
6,868
8,055



% within diab
14.7%
85.3%
100.0%



Manual calculations
\[
  RD = 25.6\% - 13.6\%  = 12\%
  \]


Interpretation


‚ö†Ô∏è Remember, this may only be an apparent association
The risk of periodontitis is 12 percentage points higher in the exposed group than in the unexposed group.
This means for every 100 people, about 12 more cases of periodontitis occur among those with diabetes.


\[
  RR = \frac{25.6\%}{13.6\%} = 1.88
  \]


Interpretation


Individuals with diabetes have 1.88 times the risk of periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.


\[
  OR = \frac{25.6/74.4}{13.6/86.4} = \frac{25.6 \times 86.4}{74.4 \times 13.6} = \frac{2211.84}{1011.84} = 2.19
  \]


Interpretation


People with diabetes have 2.19 times higher odds of having periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.

title: Praktikum 2
text:
Task 5


Timer

                    
                    
                

Create a scatterplot for the covariation of weight ~ height
üí° In SPSS: GRAFIK ‚Üí DIAGRAMMDARSTELLUNG ‚Äì Streu/-Punktdiagramm ausw√§hlen
Draw a regression line.
üí° SPSS: Double-click on the created graph, then click the symbol marked below.



Result

title: Praktikum 2
text:
Task 6


Timer

                    
                    
                

Calculate the covariance and the Pearson correlation coefficient for the relationship between height and weight.
üí° In SPSS: ANALYSIEREN ‚Üí KORRELATIONEN ‚Üí BIVARIAT - Korrelationskoeffizienten: Pearson ausw√§hlen


Result

Correlations




weight
height




weight




Pearson Correlation
1
.466**


Sig. (2-tailed)

< .001


N
15,095

height




Pearson Correlation
.466**
1

< .001



N
14,879
15,148



Note: **.Correlation is significant at the 0.01 level (2-tailed)
r = 0.466 indicates a moderate positive linear correlation:
As height increases, weight tends to increase as well.
The p-value < 0.001 shows this association is statistically significant.

title: Praktikum 2
text:
Additional task
Calculate the Spearman correlation coefficient for the relationship between age and number of teeth.
üí° In SPSS: ANALYSIEREN ‚Üí KORRELATIONEN ‚Üí BIVARIAT - Korrelationskoeffizienten: Spearman ausw√§hlen


Result

Spearman‚Äôs rho Correlations




age
nteeth




age




Correlation Coefficient
1.000
‚àí.560**


Sig. (2-tailed)
.
< .001


N
16,588
14,394


nteeth




Correlation Coefficient
‚àí.560**
1.000


Sig. (2-tailed)
< .001
.


N
14,394
14,394



Note: **.Correlation is significant at the 0.01 level (2-tailed)
œÅ = ‚àí0.560 indicates a significant, moderately strong negative monotonic association between age and number of teeth.
This means that, in general, as age increases, the number of teeth decreases.

title: Praktikum
text:
We will use data from the NHANES (National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey) for the years 1999‚Äì2003. NHANES is a cross-sectional study based on a random sample designed to describe the health status of the U.S. population. We restrict the analysis to individuals aged 30 to 85 years.
The data are stored in a file named nhanes30.sav.






.sav?



.sav extension indicates an SPSS file, which contains the observed data, variable descriptions, and metadata.
